title: Quarto Basics
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure¬†1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()





Figure¬†1: A line plot on a polar axis

title: Quarto Testing
text:
(This is really a test as to whether or not I ended up setting up the blog with gh-pages correctly.) I‚Äôm clearly not getting something really basic here. Does this change the html?
Okay, I think I‚Äôve got the html rendering except for the bulleted lists. Can I make this go live on github pages?

title: Quarto Testing
text:
Subheading test
Let‚Äôs make a bulleted list: - Item 1 - Item The Second - Item iii - There is no Item 4 - Five just came alive!
Let‚Äôs try the other type of bulleted list: + Item a + Item b + Item 3 + Item d
What if I really wanted to quote something here: > To be, or not to be, that is the question: Whether ‚Äôtis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles And by opposing end them. To die‚Äîto sleep, No more; and by a sleep to say we end The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to: ‚Äôtis a consummation Devoutly to be wish‚Äôd.
Now I want to try a numbered list: 1. Bread 1. Milk 1. Flour 1. Butter 1. Cheese 1. Havarti 1. Mozzarella 1. Gruyere 1. Beer 1. Budweiser 1. New Belgium 1. Fat Tire 2. Voodoo Ranger 1. Voodoo Ranger IPA 1. Voodoo Ranger Imperial 1. Voodoo Ranger Juicy Haze 1. Old Tuffy 1. Trippel 1. 1554 1. Coors

Subheading test
If I was clever, I would insert an image here as a test.



IMG_5954.jpeg



4th level subheading test
What else can I test here?  I can make things bold or italic.  I can insert an equation: \(\sum \vec{F} = m\vec{a}\)
